title: 109_s56
content:
The "Rio Grande Natural Area Act" establishes the Rio Grande Natural Area and defines key terms such as Commission and Secretary. The Rio Grande Natural Area in Colorado is established to conserve natural, historic, cultural, and wildlife resources along the Rio Grande River. Boundaries extend a quarter mile on each side of the river. A map and legal description will be prepared by the Secretary. The map and legal description of the Rio Grande Natural Area will have the same legal force as if included in the Act, with the Secretary able to make minor corrections. They will be available for public inspection at Bureau of Land Management offices. Establishment of the Commission. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission is established to advise the Secretary on the Natural Area and prepare a management plan for non-Federal land. The Commission consists of 9 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives from the Bureau of Land Management, Alamosa National Wildlife Refuge, Colorado Division of Wildlife, Colorado Division of Water Resources, and Rio Grande Water. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission consists of 9 members appointed by the Governor of Colorado, including representatives from various organizations and members from the general public with knowledge and experience in preservation, restoration, and use of the Natural Area. Members serve a 5-year term and may be reappointed upon completion of their term. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission consists of 9 members appointed by the Governor of Colorado for 5-year terms, with the possibility of reappointment. Members serve without compensation, elect a chairperson, hold quarterly public meetings, and receive technical assistance from federal agencies. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission consists of 9 members appointed by the Governor of Colorado for 5-year terms. Notice of any meeting of the Commission must be published in advance. The Secretary and heads of other Federal agencies must provide information and technical services requested by the Commission. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission consists of 9 members appointed by the Governor of Colorado for 5-year terms. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 5. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission may hold hearings, meetings, and take testimony to carry out the Act. They can enter into cooperative agreements with the State of Colorado or other entities to manage non-Federal land in the Natural Area. The agreements must include procedures for notifying the Commission of any actions that may impact the management plan. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission may assist the Secretary in implementing the management plan by preserving and interpreting natural resources. They are prohibited from acquiring real property and must not enlarge or diminish Federal agency rights under Federal law. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission may assist in preserving and interpreting the natural, historic, cultural, scientific, scenic, wildlife, and recreational resources of the Natural Area. They can help the State of Colorado in preserving state land and wildlife, increasing public awareness, and encouraging land use policies consistent with the management plan. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission encourages political subdivisions in Colorado to adopt land use policies consistent with the management plan for the Natural Area. They also assist private landowners in implementing the management plan. The Rio Grande Natural Area Commission encourages political subdivisions in Colorado to adopt land use policies consistent with the management plan for the Natural Area. They also assist private landowners in implementing the management plan. SEC. 6. MANAGEMENT PLAN. The Secretary and the Commission, along with relevant agencies and landowners, must prepare management plans for the Natural Area within 4 years of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will handle Federal land management, while the Commission will manage non-Federal land and submit their plan to the Secretary for approval. The Commission must submit the management plan for the Natural Area to the Secretary for approval or disapproval. If disapproved, the Secretary will take action accordingly. If the management plan for the Natural Area is disapproved, the Commission must notify the Commission of the reasons and allow for revisions to be submitted. The Secretary and the Commission must cooperate to ensure consistent management plans for Federal and non-Federal land. The plans should consider existing Federal, State, and local plans to create a unified preservation, restoration, and conservation plan for the Natural Area. Federal land management plans must comply with relevant laws and be in line with adjacent land management plans. The Natural Area management plan should be consistent with adjacent land management plans and considered an amendment to the San Luis Resource Management Plan. It should include an inventory of resources and recommendations for resource management to protect the area's resources and provide for solitude and quiet use. The management plan for the Natural Area should recommend policies for resource management, including intergovernmental agreements to protect resources and preserve solitude and natural values. The Secretary is required to publish notice of the management plans in the Federal Register. SEC. 7. ADMINISTRATION OF NATURAL AREA. The Secretary administers the Federal land in the Natural Area in accordance with laws and the management plan, focusing on conservation, restoration, and protection of natural resources. Limited public recreation and scientific study are allowed, with a prohibition on water storage facilities. The Natural Area is established for wildlife habitat protection, with a prohibition on water storage facilities and reduction in roads and motorized vehicles. The Secretary is encouraged to negotiate with stakeholders for beneficial streamflow changes. The Secretary is encouraged to negotiate with stakeholders for beneficial streamflow changes and manage private land in the Natural Area with the landowner's agreement. Federal land in the Natural Area is withdrawn from various activities, and the Secretary may acquire land from willing sellers. The Secretary may acquire land in the Natural Area from willing sellers through purchase, exchange, or donation, to be administered according to the management plan and this Act. Section 5(d)(1) of the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act does not apply to the Natural Area. SEC. 8. EFFECT.

This Act does not conflict with the Rio Grande Compact, regulate private land in the Natural Area, impose mandatory streamflow requirements, create Federal water rights, or impose stricter water quality standards. It also allows Colorado to acquire instream flow rights in the Natural Area under State law.

SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

Such sums as necessary are authorized to carry out this Act.

SEC. 10. TERMINATION OF COMMISSION.

The Commission will end 10 years after the Act's enactment.
